title: 6-year-old is Savannah's 44th homicide victim of 2016
content:
Woman, 36, also dies Wednesday in separate incident, which may be domestic dispute
UPDATE: Savannah-Chatham police arrested 45-year-old Gregory Gadson in connection with the homicide of 36-year-old Patrice Bryant. He faces murder chargers.
The case remains under investigation.
Savannah-Chatham police are investigating the slaying of a 6-year-old child and a Savannah woman in two separate incidents Wednesday afternoon.
The two homicides bring the city’s total to 44 for the year.
The first incident happened just after 12:30 p.m. Officers were called to a residence on the 800 block of East 34th Street and found Patrice Bryant, 36, dead and a 45-year-old man suffering from non-life-threatening injuries, said Darnisha Green, police spokeswoman. Investigators believe Bryant’s death resulted from a domestic incident, Baker said.
Detectives reported that they saw signs of a violent struggle inside and no signs of forced entry.
Police have not determined a cause of death in the homicide, and there was no further information on suspects or motives in the case. The roads near the house were closed for a few hours while police investigated the scene.
Boy dies at hospital after West 50th St. shooting
Just under three hours later, police responded to a shooting on West 50th Street about 2:59 p.m. and found a 6-year-old boy suffering from a gunshot wound.
The child was taken to Memorial University, where he died from his injuries, Green said. Police have not released the identity of the child, and there was no more information about the incident or suspects at press time.
Investigators are currently following and working active leads, Green said. But detectives are asking anyone with any information about the incident to come forward.
Overall, Savannah has seen more violent crime this year than it had over the same time in 2015, which was the city's most violent year since 1991.
The two shootings were not related.
Anyone with any additional information should contact the SCMPD tip line by dialing 912-525-3124.
Information may also be forwarded to CrimeStoppers at 912-234-2020. Tipsters remain anonymous and may qualify for a cash reward.
